video.description: ✨SIMPLIFIED CLASSROOM SYSTEMS✨ I used to try and do all the things…I secretly blame Pinterest for this. 😉 I thought it was normal to stay at school until 5:30 or 6 every night. I couldn’t figure out how everyone else was leaving at contract time.  If I could go back in time and give my new teacher self some advice…it would be to SIMPLIFY!!  Since simplifying to whole group classroom management, whole group instruction, and a focus on building classroom community, my entire world has changed.  I can leave at contract time without having to bring home papers to grade or unfinished lesson plans.  My students have also responded so much better to these simplified systems and it has made classroom management so much easier.  #elementaryteachertok #teachertipsandtricks #wholegroupinstruction #classroomculturematters #classroommanagementhacks #wholegroupclassroommanagement #advicefromateacher #classroomsystems

author.signature:
simple + effective K-5 classroom management 
⬇️ Classroom Management Guide

video.description: ✨CLASSROOM MANAGEMENT STRATEGY FOR MOTIVATION✨ Friday Folders were a game changer for my classroom management this year. When my students began to struggle with motivation to complete work and stay on task, I knew something had to change.  Then, I introduced Friday Folders.  These are basically a way to hold students accountable to complete work & motivate them with a fun STEM challenge or science activity every Friday.  Every student had their own folder that I managed in my filing cabinet. If they did not complete an assignment, they put their work in their Friday Folder to finish at a later time.  I have independent time built into my day, so students were allowed to work on Friday Folders during this time or anytime they finished another assignment early.  If Friday Folders were empty at the end of the day on Friday (the last 15-20 minutes) of the day, the students were able to join the Fun Friday activity.  Some of the activities we did were: homemade lava lamps, marshmallow catapults, marshmallow/spaghetti towers, ice cream in a bag, pool noodle launchers, design a maze with straws, etc. I tried to keep it simple, fun, & inexpensive.  I introduced the activity at the beginning of the week so students knew what they were working toward. It really helped with increasing motivation & work completion.  #classroommanagement #elementaryteachertok #teachertipsandtricks #classroommanagementhacks #classroommanagementtips #teachershareideas

video.description: I made this video last summer, but being prepared makes a HUGE difference with classroom management. I also recommend keeping a consistent routine: kids come in -> warm up -> go over warm up -> read -> mini lesson/go over directions/model -> independent practice -> reflect. **At my current school, we don’t independent read every day in class, but have instead dedicated Fridays to be our in-class “reading workshop” day following First Chapter Friday.  Obviously, some days are different depending on the activity, but I make sure to model my expectations and I have a slide on the board with a checklist of what I want them to accomplish.  Being intentional about your class time and being over prepared really makes a difference. I also take time to go over appropriate things they can do if they were to finish early. In my class they have 2 options: read (they are required to always have an independent reading book on them) or continue working on one of their free writes. Let me know if you have any questions! #middleschoolteacher #teachersoftiktok #teachingcommunity #teachertip #newteachertip #classroommanagement

Have the players sit in a circle of chairs, alternating teams. Designate four of the chairs to be the couch. The game starts with one empty spot on the left side of the couch. Have everyone write their name on a scrap of paper and place all of the names into a bowl. Then randomly distribute these names back to the players. The goal of this game is to fill all four seats of the couch with members of your team. Whoever has the empty seat on their left will call out the name of somebody in the circle. The person that drew that name will then get up and then move to the empty seat. Play continues by once again having the person with the empty seat on their left call out a name. Now the tricky part of this game is that the names that the players drew in the beginning have become their new names for the duration of this game. So when you call Sarah, actual Sarah is likely not the person who is coming to sit next to you. So as you learn everyone's new names, your goal will be to try to pull people from the other team off of the couch, put people from your own team onto the couch, while trying to keep all of the jumbled names together in your head. And when the whole couch is filled with members of your team, you win.

Give them the time that they need to recollect themselves and join the school community. And the third one is loss of privilege. These are not listed in any order or anything. So this means that whatever it is that the student is doing or misusing, let's say they're misusing their technology, they are no longer allowed to use that technology for a certain chunk of time. Maybe a class period or the day. It is important that the student is able to earn that opportunity back. Now, in general, when it comes to consequences, like a lot of us have different behavior management systems, point systems, class competitions, things like that that we use. The other thing to think about is to lean more in a positive direction than a negative direction. Here is a quick and enjoyable game to help your children learn their spellings. I like to call the game spelling shower and all you'll need are some torn up pieces of scrap paper, big enough so the children can write the words on but small enough so you're not wasting paper. You will then ask the children to write a certain word on their piece of paper. So for example it might be accident. They need to write the word on the piece of paper and then once they've written the word and they think it's spelled correctly without showing anybody they fold the piece of paper up into a tiny ball. I have to remind my learners not to fold it too small because it has to be unfolded later on. When everybody is ready and all their pieces are folded up into a small ball on the count of three I will ask the learners to throw it into the centre of the classroom. Now obviously this does require a little bit of behaviour management and it also depends on the logistics of your classroom. I'm lucky enough to have quite a big space in the middle where I can do this safely. Once all pieces of paper are thrown into the middle I will then ask each table to come up and choose a new piece of paper, preferably not the one that they threw and it is their job to unfold the piece of paper and check the spelling.
